text: The Big Bad Wolf is a wolf and a fictional villain in many fairy tales, such as The Boy Who Cried Wolf, Little Red Riding Hood and The Three Little Pigs. ==Symbols== Medieval people did not like wolves because wolves would eat their sheep and other animals, so sometimes the big bad wolf in the story is supposed to be a wolf and does not represent anything else. But other times the wolf is symbol for something else. There are two main ways to look at symbols in Little Red Riding Hood: In one, the girl Riding Hood is a symbol for the sun. She is eaten by the wolf, who is a symbol for winter or night. Little Red Riding Hood escaping from the wolf's belly is like the sun rising again the next day or spring coming again the next year.Alan Dundes, "Intrepreting Little Red Riding Hood Psychoanalytically", p 26-7, James M. McGlathery, ed. The Brothers Grimm and Folktale, Maria Tatar, p 25, The Annotated Classic Fairy Tales, In the other, the wolf represents sex or rape.Jane Yolen, Touch Magic p 25, Catherine Orenstein, Little Red Riding Hood Uncloaked: Sex, Morality, and the Evolution of a Fairy Tale, p 145, In French around the time Little Red Riding Hood' was written down, the figure of speech "she has seen the wolf" means "she has had sex and is not a virgin any more." ==In folklore== ===Aesop's Fables=== * "The Boy Who Cried Wolf" * "The Dog and the Wolf" * "The Priest and the Wolf" * "The Wolf and the Crane" * "The Wolf and the Lamb" * "The Wolf in Sheep's Clothing" ===Grimm's Fairy Tales=== * "Little Red Riding Hood" * "The Wolf and the Fox" * "The Wolf and the Seven Young Kids" ===English Fairy Tales by Joseph Jacobs=== * The Three Little Pigs ===Musical works by Sergei Prokofiev=== * Peter and the Wolf ==In other things== There are also modern versions of the Big Bad Wolf. For example, in the graphic novel series Fables, Bigby Wolf lives with other fairy tale characters who have run away to the real world and works as a detective. ==References== Category:Fairy tales Category:Legendary creatures
